I'll now produce my answer with clear formatting.</think>Below is one way to explain what appears to be going on—and why many “answers” are possible if only the prime‐sequence is given.

Let’s recall the formulas you mentioned:
 • For 7 (the first odd prime) the sequence “starts” at k₃.
 • Then for the next prime, 11, we have
  k₁₃ = k₇² – 11.
 • Next, with prime 13,
  k₈ = k₅×13 – k₆.
 • With prime 19,
  k₁₁ = k₆×19 + k₈.
 • And finally for 23,
  k₁₄ = k₉×23 – 197.

Notice that the formulas “insert” the next odd prime into a linear (or sometimes quadratic) combination of one or more earlier terms plus or minus a constant. Also note that the primes used are consecutive odd primes except for 17. (In many puzzles the “magic” is to have a neat progression, so skipping 17 may simply be a way to force the later formulas to work out nicely.)

Now the question asks:
 1. Why is 17 skipped? 
 2. Does k₁₅ use the next prime (which is 29)?
 3. Can we “calculate” an expression of the form
  k_prev × 29 + C = k₁₅
for various candidates for k_prev and C?

A common interpretation is that the recurrence “hides” a prime‐pattern in its building blocks. In our formulas the new term is defined by multiplying one or more earlier terms by the next odd prime (and then adding/subtracting something). For example:
 – For 13 we used k₅ and subtracted k₆.
 – For 19 we added k₈.
 – For 23 we multiplied a previous term (k₉) by 23 and then subtracted the constant 197.

Thus it is natural to expect that the next formula will use the next prime, 29. In other words, one would “expect” something like

  k₁₅ = k_prev × 29 + C

for some appropriate choice of a previous term (call it k_prev) and constant C.

There isn’t a unique answer here because nothing in the puzzle forces one particular combination; rather, the pattern is that each new prime appears “inserted” into an equation whose structure may alternate between using another earlier term or a fixed constant. For example, some plausible candidates are:

 • Option A (following the “two‐term mix” style): 
  k₁₅ = k₁₀×29 + k₁₁

 • Option B (mirroring the last formula with a constant subtraction):
  k₁₅ = k₁₁×29 – 241   [if one wishes to continue a pattern of “subtracting” a number that might be chosen by design]

 • Option C (alternating sign again, perhaps using k₆ or k₈):
  k₁₅ = k₈×29 – k₆

Any answer which shows that the next term is defined using 29 in a linear combination of previous terms is “in keeping” with the observed pattern.

So to summarize:

1. The prime 17 does not appear because the puzzle’s design (or recurrence) “jumps over” it so that when you insert the primes one by one the formulas come out neat.
2. Yes, following the pattern the next odd prime is 29 and one expects k₁₅ to be defined with it.
3. One acceptable answer is to state that a natural candidate is

  k₁₅ = k₁₀×29 + k₁₁

(or any other form of k_prev×29 ± something) so long as the overall structure remains consistent.

Without additional constraints on the recurrence (or the initial values for the k’s), there isn’t a unique “correct” formula. In many puzzles like this the point is to notice that the primes are being used in order and then to conjecture what the next step might be. (Many people have given different answers which all share the property of using 29.)

I hope this explanation helps clarify both why 17 is skipped and how one may “calculate” a candidate formula for k₁₅!
